title: Acoustic Anomaly Detection on UAM Propeller Defect
author: Juho Lee (Korea University), Donghyun Yoon (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology), Gumoon Jeong (Korea Airforce Academy), Hyeoncheol Kim (Korea University)
relevance_why: The paper discusses a methodology for non-destructive defect detection using acoustic signals, which aligns closely with audio anomaly detection techniques beneficial for Haohe's focus on audio and speech processing.
background: The study aims to detect cracks in Urban Air Mobility (UAM) propellers by analyzing drone propeller sounds to enhance maintenance systems.
contribution: This paper introduces a novel anomaly detection framework that leverages both Fast Fourier Transform and Short-Time Fourier Transform techniques to detect defects in UAM propellers via acoustic signals.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing approaches mainly rely on either Fast Fourier Transform or Short-Time Fourier Transform alone for signal analysis.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by combining both techniques to capture comprehensive frequency patterns and time-frequency variations, enhancing detection accuracy.

key_innovation: The fusion of FFT and STFT preprocessing techniques allows for a more effective acoustic pattern recognition, capable of identifying subtle defects.
real_world_impact: The findings have the potential to significantly improve the maintenance protocols of UAM systems, ensuring higher safety standards in urban air travel.
limitations: The study does not address noise interference from various environments, which may affect detection accuracy.

new_terms.Urban Air Mobility (UAM): **Urban Air Mobility (UAM)** refers to a new air transportation system utilizing vertical takeoff and landing aircraft for passenger or cargo transport in urban settings.
